question: Question_02_(d)
statement:
Suppose the tangent line to the graph of \emph{y} = $f(x)$ at
\emph{x} = 1 is \emph{y} = 2\emph{x} + 1, and $f$(3) = 2.

(d) Suppose $f$ has an inverse function $f$\textsuperscript{-1}. Given the
information from previous parts of this question, there is one number
\emph{c} for which both $f$\textsuperscript{-1}(\emph{c}) and
($f$\textsuperscript{-1})'(\emph{c}) can be found. What are \emph{c},
$f$\textsuperscript{-1}(\emph{c}) and ($f$\textsuperscript{-1})'(c)?
